text.author: Michal Lisnyansky Bar-El, Su Youn Lee, Ah Young Ki, Noa Kapelushnik, Anat Loewenstein, Ka Young Chung, Dina Schneidman-Duhovny, Moshe Giladi, Hadas Newman, Yoni Haitin
text.title: Structural Characterization of Full-Length Human Dehydrodolichyl Diphosphate Synthase Using an Integrative Computational and Experimental Approach

p.s: Protein

N-glycosylation is a critical post-translational modification , in which an oligosaccharide moiety is transferred from the glycosyl carrier dolichol-phosphate ( Dol-P ) and covalently attaches to a polypeptide chain via an asparagine residue .
Following protein conjugation , the oligosaccharide is further modified , increasing the functional and structural diversity of the proteome .
Indeed , this modification is crucial for proper protein folding , oligomerization , quality control , sorting , and transport .

Accordingly , even slight variations in protein glycosylation can markedly affect proteins structure and function and , thus , glycosylation disorders result in a wide range of clinical syndromes affecting practically every organ system .

Dehydrodolichyl diphosphate synthase ( DHDDS ) together with Nogo-B receptor ( NgBR ) form the human
cis
-prenyltransferase complex .
This complex catalyzes the formation of dehydrodolichyl diphosphate ( DHDD ) , a long-chain polyprenyl serving as a precursor for Dol-P .

DHDD is synthesized by chain elongation of farnesyl diphosphate ( FPP ) via multiple condensations with isopentenyl diphosphate ( IPP ) (
Figure 1
A ) .

Importantly , while previous studies revealed that DHDDS is required and sufficient for this catalytic activity , NgBR induces an increase in the expression and activity of the complex but exhibits no catalytic activity .

In line with the important role of DHDDS in protein glycosylation , mutations in DHDDS were recently shown to cause autosomal recessive retinitis pigmentosa , a fatal glycosylation disorder , and developmental epileptic encephalopathies .
Despite the clinical importance of DHDDS , it was not structurally and functionally characterized to date .

Conserved domains search analysis reveals that the
cis
-prenyltransferase catalytic domain of DHDDS ( residues 24 – 248 ) is homologous to undecaprenyl pyrophosphate synthase ( UPPS ) , a well characterized bacterial
cis
-prenyltransferase .
Consisting of seven α-helices and six β-strands , this domain forms dimers , with a hydrophobic catalytic tunnel surrounded by two α-helices and four β−strands within each monomer .

In contrast with the N-terminal
cis
-prenyltransferase homology domain , the C-terminus of human DHDDS does not converge with any known conserved domains .

Intriguingly , despite the low level of conservation , a C-terminal domain is common to long-chain
cis
-prenyltransferases and is absent in short- and medium-chain
cis
-prenyltransferases (
Figure 1
B ) .
Nevertheless , its structure and functional role remains elusive .

Recently , we have devised an efficient procedure for overexpression and purification of human DHDDS in
Escherichia coli
.
Similar to the bacterial homolog UPPS , we showed that human DHDDS forms active homodimers .
However , the molecular details of the interaction interface and the overall architecture of the enzyme remained obscure .

Here , we determine a structural model for the full-length human DHDDS homodimer using an integrative approach that combines multiple sources of information , including a radioligand-based enzyme kinetics assay , size-exclusion chromatography multi-angle light scattering ( SEC-MALS ) , small-angle X-ray scattering ( SAXS ) , and hydrogen – deuterium exchange mass-spectrometry ( HDX-MS ) .
